article.description: Connecticut (No. 1 ESPN/USA Today, No. 2 AP) could do little wrong in its 97-42 rout of slumping Pittsburgh. The host Huskies (21-2, 11-1 Big East) had season highs in points, 3-pointers (12) and steals (18).
article.headline: Former Huskies great on Pitt bench
article.linkText: UConn reserves outscore Pittsburgh in rout
article.story:
HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) -- Connecticut (No. 1 ESPN/USA Today, No. 2 AP) could do little wrong in its 97-42 rout of slumping Pittsburgh.

The Huskies (21-2, 11-1 Big East) had season highs in points,
3-pointers (12) and steals (18). There was plenty for the crowd of
16,294 to cheer about, but the fans may have saved one of their
loudest ovations for a member of the opposition.

The game marked the homecoming of sorts for Pittsburgh assistant
coach Shea Ralph, a former UConn All-America who drew a standing
ovation during introductions. Ralph helped lead the Huskies to a
national title in 2000 and was named the MVP of that Final Four.
She spent several minutes before the game signing jerseys, balls
and programs for several children.

"It was just neat to come back and have a reception like
that," Ralph said. "They really are my family. Not just the team,
the coaches and the support staff. These fans, they come up and
remember. I'm with a different team now, and that's where my
loyalties are, but Connecticut is always going to be my family."

UConn star Diana Taurasi, who had 11 points and eight assists,
said it meant a lot to see Ralph again.

"We go back to the very first day I stepped on campus for my
visit," Taurasi said. "I stayed with her. She kind of talked me
through things and really helped me out."

The reception UConn gave the Panthers was a different story as the Huskies picked up their 10th straight win.

Led by Ashley Battle, who had 15 points and five steals, the
Huskies dominated in every area of the game. Coach Geno Auriemma
emptied his bench late in the first half, and by the final buzzer
the reserves accounted for 56 points. Taurasi played just 22
minutes.

"I thought [Taurasi] played great tonight. She didn't have to
take many shots or make a lot of shots, and we rest her as much as
we can for the stretch run," Auriemma said. "We're playing some
really good basketball right now."

Katie Histed and Jennifer Brown had 12 points apiece for the
overmatched Panthers (6-17, 2-11), who have lost nine straight.

Liz Sherwood, UConn's reserve freshman center, scored a
career-high 14 points on 6-of-7 shooting.

UConn hit seven 3-pointers in the first half and scored 26 points on turnovers to build a 56-21 lead. The half featured a decisive 30-4 run that included 10 points by Sherwood. Sherwood, who is 6-foot-4, hit all five of her first-half shots with strong inside moves.

"It's always a post player's dream to just turn and score, and
that's pretty much what I did, so it was great," Sherwood said.

The 56 points were the most for a half since the 2002 season,
when the Huskies scored 56 in both the first and second halves
against the Panthers.

The Huskies outscored Pittsburgh 50-14 in the paint and had 38
points off 24 turnovers. UConn also was solid from the perimeter,
hitting 12-of-20 from beyond the 3-point line.

"Playing in an environment like this, it's very easy for a team
to break," Pittsburgh coach Agnus Berenato said. "Playing a team
like UConn, we know we can't compete, but I felt that we didn't
give up."

Ralph said that despite the lopsided score, the game allowed the
players to see what can be accomplished.

"When you're trying to build a program, I think a game like this
is monumental," Shea said. "In order to get better, you've got to
play the best. And that's what we did tonight."
